title: 110_hr3678
content:
The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes from 2007 to 2014. It also includes provisions for grandfathering states that tax internet access. Section 1104 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) effective as of November 1, 2003. The definition of 'Internet access' is clarified in Section 1104 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act, as amended on October 21, 1998, and further amended by the Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act. Exceptions to this definition apply until June 30, 2008, for taxes on Internet access that are imposed on telecommunications services used by Internet providers. The Internet Tax Freedom Act clarifies the definition of 'Internet access' and provides exceptions for taxes on telecommunications services used by Internet providers until June 30, 2008. Taxes on Internet access must be consistent with certain conditions, including public rulings or ongoing litigation before July 1, 2007. The Internet Tax Freedom Act sets conditions for taxing telecommunications services used by Internet providers, with exceptions until June 30, 2008. No legislative inference can be made from this subsection for taxes prior to June 30, 2008. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of "Internet access" as a service enabling users to connect to the Internet for content and services. This includes the purchase, use, or sale of telecommunications by providers to facilitate this service. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act is clarified to include telecommunications used to provide the service and enable users to access content and services. This also encompasses incidental services like home pages, email, and instant messaging. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes telecommunications used to provide the service and enable access to content and services. It also covers incidental services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. Voice, audio, and video programming, as well as other products and services utilizing Internet protocol, are not included in this definition. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act excludes voice, audio, and video programming, as well as other products and services utilizing Internet protocol, that have a charge. It includes services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. The term 'telecommunications' in the Communications Act of 1934 includes telecommunications services and is defined separately from Internet access services. The term 'tax on Internet access' does not include a State tax on commercial activity effective November 1, 2007. Effective November 1, 2007, the term 'tax on Internet access' excludes State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses. The tax legislation enacted between June 20, 2005, and November 1, 2007, or between January 1, 1932, and January 1, 1936, must meet specific criteria to be considered a tax on Internet access. Tax legislation enacted between January 1, 1932, and January 1, 1936, must meet specific criteria to be considered a tax on Internet access, including being imposed on a broad range of business activity and not discriminatory towards communication services providers. After January 1, 1936, states can modify taxes on Internet access as long as they don't significantly limit the range of taxed activities or disqualify the tax. No conclusions about other tax applications can be drawn from these modifications. No legislative construction inference can be made regarding the application of certain taxes before November 1, 2007. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to replace "telecommunications services" with "telecommunications" and expand the definition to include enabling users to access content online. Additionally, a section related to voice services is removed from the Act. SEC. 6. SUNSET OF GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS.

Amendment to the Internet Tax Freedom Act states that states which repealed taxes on Internet access more than 24 months prior to enactment are exempt from certain provisions.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective from November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, except as specified in section 1104 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
